z:row.TitlePrimary: Edge turbulence in Tokamaks
z:row.TitleSecondary: Plasma Physics and Controlled Nucelar Fusion Research. Proceedings of the Ninth International Conference, 1-8 Sept. 1982
z:row.Keyword: fusion reactor theory and design|plasma confinement|plasma instability|plasma magnetohydrodynamics
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Baltimore, MD, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The experimental data on the high level of turbulence in the edge of Tokamaks is discussed in terms of theoretical models. The `rippling' resistive MHD instability is advanced as a candidate for this turbulence. The linear, quasilinear and turbulent regimes of the rippling instability are investigated with a combination of computational models and analytic treatments. Parallel electron heat conduction effects are included and found ultimately to limit the modes' spatial extent and induced transport. A number of features of rippling mode turbulence (poloidal and radial correlation lengths of the potential and magnetic fluctuations, dominance of low-frequency components, etc.) are found to be in reasonable agreement with experimental observations of edge turbulence. In addition to its possible relevance to Tokamak edge turbulence, the model developed illustrates the interplay and ultimate effects of a number of nonlinear processes in resistive MHD turbulence
z:row.User2: Tokamaks; MHD instability; electron heat conduction effects; rippling mode turbulence; edge turbulence

z:row.TitlePrimary: Neoclassical flows and transport in nonaxisymmetric toroidal plasmas
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Nuclear Engng. Dept., Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The moment equation approach to neoclassical transport theory has been generalized to nonaxisymmetric toroidal systems under the assumption of the existence of magnetic surfaces. In particular, the parallel plasma flows and bootstrap current are calculated in both the Pfirsch-Schluter and banana regimes. It is found that both parallel plasma flows and the bootstrap current can be reduced as the toroidal bumpiness increases in an otherwise axisymmetric system
z:row.User2: neoclassical flows; Pfirsch-Schluter regime; nonaxisymmetric toroidal plasmas; moment equation approach; neoclassical transport theory; magnetic surfaces; plasma flows; bootstrap current; banana regimes

z:row.TitlePrimary: Confinement and heating in modular and continuous coil stellarators
z:row.TitleSecondary: Plasma Physics and Controlled Nucelar Fusion Research. Proceedings of the Ninth International Conference, 1-8 Sept. 1982
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Baltimore, MD, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Torsatron/Stellarator Lab., Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Major efforts on the Proto-Cleo stellarator have focused on ICRH of a net current-free plasma, measurements of plasma secondary currents, RF heating by externally induced magnetic reconnection through the formation and destruction of an internal separatrix, and RF current drive experiments. Efforts on the Proto-Cleo torsatron have focused on electron heat conduction. A modular stellarator has been designed and is under fabrication at the University of Wisconsin. The Interchangeable Module Stellarator (IMS) is designed to approximate closely the magnetic properties of the existing Proto-Cleo stellarator as much as possible. Monte-Carlo transport calculations have been made in flux coordinates using model fields patterned after magnetic fields in Proto-Cleo and IMS. Plasma simulation techniques using a 21/2-dimensional particle-in-cell method have been utilized in a numerical search for the bootstrap current. A current is found which is proportional to temperature and density gradients but is independent of poloidal field. The behaviour of charged particles moving in a stellarator under the influence of a steady magnetic field is analysed in terms of the Hamiltonian of the moving particle and the technique of repeated canonical transformations to identify possible adiabatic invariants and drift motions
z:row.User2: heating; continuous coil stellarators; Proto-Cleo stellarator; ICRH; net current-free plasma; plasma secondary currents; RF heating; electron heat conduction; modular stellarator; Interchangeable Module Stellarator; Monte-Carlo transport calculations

z:row.TitlePrimary: UWTOR-M, a stellarator power reactor utilizing modular coils
z:row.TitleSecondary: Fusion Reactor Design and Technology. Proceedings of the 3rd Technical Committee Meeting and Workshop, 5-16 Oct. 1981
z:row.TitleTertiary: Fusion Reactor Design and Technology. Proceedings of the 3rd Technical Committee Meeting and Workshop
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Tokyo, Japan
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Nuclear Engng. Dept., Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A preliminary design of a 5500 MWth modular stellarator power reactor, UWTOR-M, is presented. The authors briefly describe the parametric considerations which led to the UWTOR-M reference design point. The natural stellarator divertor is used for impurity control in conjunction with innovative high performance divertor targets. A unique blanket design is proposed which minimizes tritium inventory in the reactor. Finally, since maintainability is a prime consideration, the authors describe a scheme for servicing the first wall/blanket and other reactor components
z:row.User2: modular coils; preliminary design; stellarator power reactor; UWTOR-M; stellarator divertor; impurity control; divertor targets; blanket design; tritium inventory; servicing

z:row.TitlePrimary: Recent experiments in the Phaedrus tandem mirror
z:row.TitleSecondary: Plasma Physics and Controlled Nucelar Fusion Research. Proceedings of the Ninth International Conference, 1-8 Sept. 1982
z:row.Keyword: fusion reactor theory and design|plasma confinement|plasma instability|plasma magnetohydrodynamics
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Baltimore, MD, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Nuclear Engng. Dept., Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A stable, steady tandem mirror plasma is sustained by RF alone in the Phaedrus tandem mirror experiment. RF trapping of central-cell stream provides plug fuelling and Monte Carlo simulations predict many of its characteristics. The MHD stability of the Phaedrus tandem mirror plasma is shown to be in agreement with predictions of pressure-weighted minimum-|B| stability theory. Reduction of the ion end loss flux due to electrostatic confinement of central-cell ions is observed both statically and dynamically. Direct fuelling of the plugs by gas puffing and RF trapping has also been demonstrated.-In addition, neutral-beam injection into RF-sustained plasmas is described; significant increases in diamagnetism and density have been obtained. Preliminary experiments with breakdown and heating with ECRF are also described
z:row.User2: Phaedrus tandem mirror; RF trapping; plug fuelling; Monte Carlo simulations; MHD stability; ion end loss flux; electrostatic confinement; neutral-beam injection

z:row.TitlePrimary: THERMAL BARRIER ION TRAPPING RATE IN A TANDEM MIRROR
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Nuclear Engineering Dep, Madison, Wis, USA
z:row.Abstract: An analytic expression for the Coulomb collision induced ion trapping rate in the thermal barrier cell of a tandem mirror has been obtained. The overall system is assumed to be maintained in steady state by particle injection in the central cell and charge-exchange pumping in the barrier cell. For small ratios of bounce-to-collision time scales the problem reduces to a series of boundary value problems in the various regions of phase space. For conditions of interest, pitch-angle trapping is dominant and a Lorentz collision operator describes reasonably well the kinetic problem, which is solved using a square-well approximation. The analytic results are found to agree with numerical results within expected limits, on the order of the inverse of the barrier/mirror ratio approximately (10 to 20%).
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved

z:row.TitlePrimary: Dynamic electrostatic confinement in an RF-sustained tandem mirror
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Nuclear Engng. Dept., Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Electrostatic ion confinement is demonstrated in an RF-sustained tandem mirror and shown to have a dynamic nature. Measurements of plasma potential and ion end loss on particular flux tubes show that confinement can be enhanced by a factor of 3 over direct- flow loss rates. The axial confining potential can vary with radial position and time resulting in changes in ion confinement with abrupt reductions in central-cell plasma density and axial potential confinement is reduced
z:row.User2: electrostatic ion confinement; RF-sustained tandem mirror; plasma potential; ion end loss; flow loss rates; central-cell plasma density

z:row.TitlePrimary: Boundary layer corrections to neoclassical ripple transport in Tokamaks
z:row.Keyword: plasma confinement|plasma heating|plasma instability|plasma transport processes
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Nuclear Engng. Dept., Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The discrete nature of the toroidal magnetic field coils spoils the symmetry of the Tokamak and creates small modulations of the toroidal field called ripples. Particles trapped in the ripple well drift off the flux surface and enhance both particle and heat fluxes. In the usual ripple transport calculations, the derivative of the perturbed particle distribution function in velocity space is discontinuous at the boundary between the ripple trapped and untrapped regions. To smooth out the particle distribution across the boundary, the particle distribution in the boundary layer is calculated by using the Wiener-Hopf technique. The correction to the ripple-trapped particle distribution function away from the boundary laser and the ripple transport associated with it are obtained. It is found that the particle diffusion and heat conduction coefficients are increased by about a factor of 2 and scale like ν-1/2 as (νeff/ωbδ)1/2→1. Even for very collisionless plasmas, νeff/ωbδ=10-2, the corrections are still non-negligible and are about 15%
z:row.User2: neoclassical ripple transport; Tokamaks; toroidal magnetic field coils; ripple transport calculations; velocity space; Wiener-Hopf technique; ripple-trapped particle distribution function; boundary laser; particle diffusion and heat conduction coefficients

z:row.TitlePrimary: NEOCLASSICAL RIPPLE TRANSPORT IN TOKAMAKS
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: UNIV OF WIS, MADISON, USA
z:row.Abstract: THE USUAL RIPPLE TRANSPORT CALCULATIONS LED TO A "NU" ** - **1 SCALING OF THE TRANSPORT COEFFICIENTS WITH COLLISION FREQUENCY "NU" . THIS PAPER EXTENDS AND CLARIFIES THIS SCALING BY TAKING INTO ACCOUNT THE FACT THAT THE DOMINANT CONTRIBUTIONS TO TRANSPORT COME FROM PARTICLES IN THE HIGH-ENERGY TAILOF THE DISTRIBUTION FUNCTION. IN ADDITION, TRANSPORT COEFFICIENTS ARE DERIVED IN WEAK-RIPPLE ( "ALPHA" = "EPSILON" /NQ "DELTA" > 1, WITH "EPSILON" THE INVERSE ASPECT RATIO, N THE NUMBER OF TOROIDAL COILS, Q THE SAFETY FACTOR), LOW-COLLISIONALITY REGIMES WHERE THE RADIAL STEP SIZE IS DETERMINED BY THE DISTANCE A PARTICLE DRIFTS BEFORE IT 'COLLISIONLESSLY DETRAPS' FROM A RIPPLE WELL. THE MAXIMUM TRANSPORT RATE IS FOUND TO BE ABOUT TWO ORDERS OF MAGNITUDE SMALLER THAN USUALLY ASSUMED, PRIMARILY BECAUSE OF THE RESTRICTION OF THE "NU" ** - **1 SCALING REGIME TO THE MUCH HIGHER COLLISION FREQUENCIES.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: TOKAMAK DEVICES

z:row.TitlePrimary: UWTOR-M - A CONCEPTUAL DESIGN STUDY OF A MODULAR STELLARATOR POWER REACTOR
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wis, Madison, USA
z:row.Abstract: A preliminary design of a 5500 MW//t//h modular stellarator power reactor, UWTOR-M, is presented. Discrete twisted coils are used in an l equals 3 configuration with maintainability as a prime consideration. The natural stellarator divertor is used for impurity control in conjunction with innovative high performance divertor targets. A unique blanket design is proposed which minimizes the overall tritium inventory in the reactor. Finally, a scheme for maintaining the first wall/blanket and other reactor components is discussed.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved

z:row.TitlePrimary: Plasma transport and impurity behaviour in the edge and divertor regions of a Tokamak
z:row.TitleSecondary: Eighth International Conference on Plasma Physics and Controlled Nuclear Fusion Research, 1-10 July 1980
z:row.Keyword: fusion reactor theory and design|Monte Carlo methods|plasma confinement|plasma impurities|plasma instability|plasma magnetohydrodynamics|plasma transport processes|Tokamak devices
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Brussels, Belgium
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A number of issues regarding impurity behaviour and plasma transport in the edge and divertor regions of a Tokamak are discussed. With regard to plasma edge and divertor effects: (1) the experimentally observed radial plasma transport is shown to significantly exceed estimates of that induced by the resistive MHD instabilities; (2) parallel mass transport into a bundle divertor is shown to be inhibited by the magnetic mirror at the divertor entrance; (3) an experimental test of the gaseous divertor concept in the QED has demonstrated a factor of 102 pressure differential and a reduction of conductance by a factor of 10; (4) a Monte-Carlo calculation of pumping by a poloidal divertor box indicates that the pumping is 1.6 to 4.3 times more efficient for hydrogen than for helium; (5) a new edge model for helium, however, including the very rapid recycling, indicates that significantly less helium pumping may be required than previously thought; and (6) variations in the energy of recycled neutrals are shown to have a large effect on the edge plasma and a noticeable effect on the central temperature
z:row.User2: Tokamak divertor region; Monte Carlo calculation; He pumping; controlled thermonuclear fusion; impurity behaviour; plasma transport; resistive MHD instabilities; parallel mass transport; bundle divertor; magnetic mirror; gaseous divertor concept; QED; poloidal divertor box; edge model; rapid recycling; edge plasma; central temperature

z:row.TitlePrimary: Recent progress in torsatron/stellarator research in the United States of America
z:row.TitleSecondary: Eighth International Conference on Plasma Physics and Controlled Nuclear Fusion Research, 1-10 July 1980
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Brussels, Belgium
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A summary of recent theoretical and experimental developments in stellarators and torsatrons is presented. MHD equilibrium calculations demonstrate the need for mixed l and l+1 helical harmonics for β limits. Harmonic decompositions of the flux surfaces in an l=2 ultimate torsatron demonstrate this proper harmonic mixing. Several different approaches to the design of modular torsatron/stellarator coils, desirable for a reactor, are presented. Other reactor considerations investigated for a classical torsatron include α-particle containment, ion thermal conductivity, magnetic well depth studies, and technology issues. Results from experiments include studies of low Ohmic-heating current discharges in the Proto-Cleo torsatron and elucidation of the role of cross-field plasma injection in producing convective cells in the Proto-Cleo stellarator
z:row.User2: harmonic decompositions; fusion reactor; alpha-particle containment; modular torsatron coil; stellarators; MHD equilibrium calculations; helical harmonics; flux surfaces; harmonic mixing

z:row.TitlePrimary: UWTOR-M, a conceptual design study of a modular stellarator power reactor
z:row.TitleSecondary: 9th Symposium on Engineering Problems of Fusion Research, 26-29 Oct. 1981
z:row.TitleTertiary: 9th Symposium on Engineering Problems of Fusion Research
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Chicago, IL, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Nuclear Engng. Dept., Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A preliminary design of a 5500 MWth modular stellarator power reactor, UWTOR-M, is presented. The authors briefly describe the parametric considerations which led to the UWTOR-M reference design point. The design has 18 twisted coils utilizing a multipolarity of 3, a major radius of 24 m, a coil radius of 4.77 m and a plasma aspect ratio of 14. An assumed β of 5% was used. This configuration leads to a rotational transform on the edge of 1.125 giving favourable plasma physics conditions. The natural stellarator divertor is used for impurity control in conjunction with innovative high performance divertor targets. A unique blanket design is proposed which minimizes tritium inventory in the reactor. Finally, since maintainability is a prime consideration, we describe a scheme for servicing the first wall/blanket and other reactor components
z:row.User2: UWTOR-M; design study; modular stellarator power reactor; multipolarity; rotational transform; stellarator divertor; blanket design

z:row.TitlePrimary: Effect of collisions on gyroresonance
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Nuclear Engng. Dept., Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The effect of collisions on ion gyroresonances in a magnetized plasma for frequencies ω≃nΩi is derived by solving the Fokker-Planck equation with a multiple-time-scale-type perturbation method. An example is given for ka≫1 with a Landau collision operator
z:row.User2: collisions effects; gyroresonance; magnetized plasma; Fokker-Planck equation; multiple-time-scale-type perturbation method; Landau collision operator

z:row.TitlePrimary: Fusion progress in the last decade
z:row.TitleSecondary: Proceedings of the 1980 Region 6 Conference `The 1980s-A Forest of Energy decision Trees', Feb. 1980
z:row.TitleTertiary: Proceedings of the 1980 Region 6 Conference `The 1980s-A Forest of Energy decision Trees'
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: San Diego, CA, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Nuclear Engng. & Phys. Dept., Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Summary form only given, as follows. Dramatic progress has been made in the past decade toward confining and heating plasmas to the conditions required for controlled thermonuclear fusion. Plasma confinement has been improved from the nτ~1011 level in the late 60s to about 3×1013-only a factor of 3 short of the minimum required-primarily through higher magnetic fields and larger plasmas. Ion temperatures have been increased from 0.5 to 6.5 keV-above the minimum required-with intense neutral beam heating. The magnetic containment efficiency has been increased from .03% to about 2% in Tokamaks, and up to about 100% in mirrors. Techniques have been developed for producing and maintaining clean (Zeff<2) plasmas, at least for short pulses. The tremendous progress in plasma parameters has been facilitated by developments in plasma technology (neutral beams, vacuum systems, magnets, pellet fuelling, etc.) and has been accompanied by a significant increase in the understanding and predictability of plasmas. While the most dramatic parameter improvements have been made in the Tokamak and magnetic mirror concepts with neutral beam heating, there have also been significant advances in alternate confinement concepts (EBTs, stellarators, multipoles, etc.) and heating schemes (radio frequency wave and adiabatic compression)
z:row.User2: controlled thermonuclear fusion; neutral beam heating; magnetic containment efficiency; Tokamak; magnetic mirror; plasma confinement; fusion reactors; plasma heating; reviews

z:row.TitlePrimary: Mirror microinstabilities in divertors
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nuclear Engng., Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Impurity control in Tokamaks may be implemented by the use of a divertor. The plasma in the divertor region may however, be unstable to minor microinstabilities which may affect plasma transport in this region
z:row.User2: Tokamaks; divertor; minor microinstabilities; plasma transport; impurity control

z:row.TitlePrimary: Collective modes in high-current-carrying confined plasmas
z:row.TitleSecondary: Proceeding of the 4th conference on plasma physics and controlled nuclear fusion research 1971, 17-23 June 1971
z:row.TitleTertiary: Proceeding of the 4th conference on plasma physics and controlled nuclear fusion research 1971
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: MIT, Cambridge, MA, USA
z:row.Abstract: The influence of the plasma cross-section profile on the maximum current density which can be achieved in two-dimensional toroidal configurations is analysed. The MHD-stability and equilibrium are examined for a plasma column with a conducting shell close to it and with an elliptic and triangular deformation imposed over a circular cross-section profile. Since the configurations of interest also have a low aspect ratio and a large fraction of trapped particles, the stability of collisionless kinetic modes involving trapped particles is studied taking into account the effect of the electron current. Effects related to simultaneous presence of different kinetic modes are considered and the possible stabilizing factors of interchange-trapped particle modes are pointed out
z:row.User2: cross section profile; magnetohydrodynamic stability; confined plasmas; maximum current density; toroidal configurations; triangular deformation; low aspect ratio; collisionless kinetic modes; trapped particles
